title: Problem Overview
content: **The Littlewood Conjecture** is one of the most famous open problems in number theory. It asks: for any two real numbers α and β, can you always find integers n that make the product n · ‖nα‖ · ‖nβ‖ arbitrarily small? Here ‖x‖ means the distance from x to the nearest whole number. Think of it as asking whether every pair of reals can be simultaneously well-approximated by fractions, in a multiplicative sense.
mathContext: The conjecture states lim inf_{n→∞} n·‖nα‖·‖nβ‖ = 0 for all α, β ∈ ℝ. This is a multiplicative strengthening of Dirichlet's theorem on simultaneous approximation. Open since c. 1930.

title: Distance to Nearest Integer
content: **distInt x** computes how far x is from the nearest whole number. For example, distInt(3.2) = 0.2 and distInt(3.8) = 0.2 (distance to 4). This is always between 0 and 1/2. In number theory notation, this is written ‖x‖ and is fundamental to measuring how well real numbers can be approximated by integers.
mathContext: distInt(x) = |x - round(x)|. Satisfies 0 ≤ distInt(x) ≤ 1/2 for all x ∈ ℝ. Both bounds are axiomatized here since the full proof requires properties of round that interact with the absolute value.

title: The Littlewood Product
content: **littlewoodProduct n α β** is the quantity n · ‖nα‖ · ‖nβ‖. This measures how well both α and β can be simultaneously approximated by rationals with denominator n. The Littlewood conjecture asserts this product can be made arbitrarily small.
mathContext: L(n, α, β) = n · ‖nα‖ · ‖nβ‖. The multiplicative structure (product of three terms) is what makes this conjecture so much harder than the additive Dirichlet theorem, which gives ‖nα‖ < 1/n for infinitely many n.

title: The Littlewood Conjecture
content: **LittlewoodConjecture** is formalized as: for every pair of reals (α, β), every ε > 0, and every starting point N, there exists n ≥ N with n · ‖nα‖ · ‖nβ‖ < ε. This 'infinitely often' formulation is equivalent to saying the liminf is zero. The conjecture has been open for nearly a century.
mathContext: LittlewoodConjecture : Prop := ∀ α β : ℝ, ∀ ε > 0, ∀ N : ℕ, ∃ n ≥ N, n ≥ 1 ∧ littlewoodProduct n α β < ε. This is equivalent to the liminf formulation but avoids needing to formalize liminf over ℕ → ℝ in the type theory.

title: Rational Case
content: **The conjecture is trivially true when α is rational.** If α = p/q, then for any multiple n of q, we have nα is an integer, so ‖nα‖ = 0 and the entire product vanishes. This is the simplest case and shows the conjecture is really about irrational numbers.
mathContext: If α = p/q with q ≥ 1, then for n = kq we get ‖nα‖ = ‖kp‖ = 0, making the Littlewood product zero. Axiomatized since the formal proof requires divisibility arguments.

title: Cassels-Swinnerton-Dyer (1955)
content: **The first non-trivial result:** Cassels and Swinnerton-Dyer proved the Littlewood conjecture holds when α and β are algebraically related cubic irrationals — for example, α = ∛2 and β = (∛2)². Their proof uses the geometry of numbers and properties of cubic number fields.
mathContext: The theorem applies when α is a root of a cubic polynomial aX³ + bX + c = 0 (a ≠ 0) and β = rα² + sα for rational r, s. This covers pairs in the same cubic field extension of ℚ. The proof was later reinterpreted in terms of dynamics on SL(3,ℝ)/SL(3,ℤ).

title: Einsiedler-Katok-Lindenstrauss (2006)
content: **The major breakthrough:** EKL proved that the set of counterexamples to the Littlewood conjecture has Hausdorff dimension zero. In simple terms, counterexamples (if they exist) are vanishingly rare — far rarer than any positive-dimensional set. This work earned Elon Lindenstrauss the 2010 Fields Medal.
mathContext: The proof uses ergodic theory on the homogeneous space SL(3,ℝ)/SL(3,ℤ), specifically the classification of invariant measures for diagonal actions (the A-action). The key insight is translating the number-theoretic problem into a question about orbit closures in a Lie group quotient. Axiomatized as True since formalizing Hausdorff dimension is beyond current Mathlib.

title: The p-adic Littlewood Conjecture
content: **A natural variant** replaces one of the ‖·‖ factors with the p-adic absolute value |·|_p. The de Mathan-Teulié conjecture (2004) asks: for every real α and prime p, is lim inf n · |n|_p · ‖nα‖ = 0? Einsiedler-Kleinbock (2007) proved the analogous Hausdorff dimension zero result. Badziahin-Velani (2014) made further progress for badly approximable numbers.
mathContext: PAdicLittlewood p : Prop := ∀ α : ℝ, ∀ ε > 0, ∀ N, ∃ n ≥ N, n ≥ 1 ∧ n · distInt(nα) < ε · n. The p-adic valuation |n|_p = p^(-v_p(n)) measures divisibility by p. This variant connects Diophantine approximation to p-adic analysis.

title: Summary and Status
content: **Status: OPEN.** The Littlewood conjecture remains one of the great unsolved problems in number theory. It is known for: (1) rational numbers (trivially), (2) cubic irrationals in the same field (Cassels-Swinnerton-Dyer 1955), (3) almost all pairs in a measure-theoretic sense (EKL 2006, Hausdorff dimension zero exceptions). The p-adic variant is also open.
mathContext: erdos_495_status : True := trivial serves as a marker that the problem has been formally documented. The conjecture itself cannot be stated as a theorem because it is unresolved. All substantial results are axiomatized.
